title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.Mrs May wants the UK to have the right to end the backstop at will - but the EU has warned that would render the mechanism pointless.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.On November , thereported that Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab demanded the right to pull Britain out of the EU’s Irish backstop after just three months.The paper claimed the hardline pitch to the Irish government “stunned” Irish officials.Its claimed Mr Raab’s proposal was put to the Irish deputy prime minister Simon Coveney in a private meeting in London.However, the Irish Prime Minister told Theresa May that he will not accept a Brexit deal which gives the UK the unilateral power to halt backstop arrangements for the border with Northern Ireland.The EU has suggested a backstop that would see Northern Ireland staying in the customs union, the EU VAT system and parts of the single market.This will essentially draw a customs border down the middle of the Irish Sea, potentially damaging the union of the UK.Mrs May has suggested a backstop that will see all of the UK aligned with the EU customs union for a limited time after .Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU thinks this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.In June  European leaders said Britain was running out of time to do a deal because of the unsolved border problem.In July Theresa May quoted Shakespeare as she insisted the UK would not be broken up with a border down the Irish Sea. Theresa May has told EU leaders she is looking at ways of keeping Britain under their rules for at least another year as part of efforts to break the Brexit deadlock.Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels on the night of October , the PM said she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.The news comes after talks on Sunday, October , hit a brick wall once again, as the issue of the Irish border continues to cause a headache for Theresa May.Theresa May has insisted any backstop arrangement must apply to the UK as a whole so not to create a border in the Irish Sea.However, talks broke down after the EU had insisted on a second backstop arrangement - just involving Northern Ireland -the UKs version wasnt ready in time, according to Downing Street sources. Mrs May dubbed the continuing row with Brussels over how to avoid a hard border in Ireland as “the one real sticking point left, but a considerable one”.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, said that EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier indicated that the European Union will allow extra time for talks about the border.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.On November , , the PM faced crunch Cabinet showdowns with her ministers where she will set out the details of the agreement she struck with Brussels the previous day.A number of pro-Brexit ministers are feared to be on the brink of walking out over the deal.They believe it would leave Britain tied to the EU customs union for years to come, because of the controversial Irish backstop arrangement.If the Cabinet does block Mrs Mays deal, she could find her position is untenable - leading to a Tory leadership crisis.

title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: family six move thirteen times four months
story: Dean and Amy Coombes were evicted from their house in St Austell, Cornwall, in June, leaving them and their four children - all aged under eight - without a home. The family have since had to live on campsites in a caravan, hotels and pubs all across England.Cornwall Council said it was supporting the family but unfortunately there is a high demand for temporary accommodation, which includes our own housing stock, properties that we rent, or other accommodation.Mr Coombes said they thought three times that their hell was over when they were told a permanent property had been found - only for the offer to be withdrawn time and time again.They say well give you a house and then the next day they say no we wont, Mr Coombes said.It feels like we are being strangled. Your hopes are up and then you are shot down again.We have run out of enthusiasm, added Mrs Coombes.We feel deflated - you want to throw the towel in. You want to give up but know you cant. The kids are the reason we havent given up.The family have had to put their belongings in storage.Mr Coombes said: We left one place in the morning, packed the car with all our bags, drove to St Austell and just waited in the car with the children.Then they rung us up and said we were booked back into the same campsite we had just left.Their child have also had to move schools as a result of the chaos.He said: We dont want much - just a bit of stability and normality for the kids.The kids are asking all of the time - they are confused and have been dragged from pillar to post. We feel guilty they are going through this.I dont want an extravagant house. I just want a place that is suitable for my family, kids and our dog. Im not asking for five acres of land and a swimming pool.Amy added: We feel let down as a family.Its been very stressful for the children - they are struggling to cope with it. Its not fair on them.Were adults - we can cope better than children.Dean said he just wanted stability.A three bedroom house is the minimum, he added. Four bedrooms would be great and five would be bliss.I look every day for private accommodation but they get snapped up. Its very stressful.Neither of us drink though Amy smokes a little.I am grateful for the accommodation weve had but it just feels like weve been failed by the council. Cornwall Council said: Unfortunately accommodation can be dficult to arrange, especially for larger families who have pets.We review the availability of accommodation on a weekly basis and will move families to a more suitable placeappropriate.There is a plan for the family to move in to a privately rented home however like any other move where more than one family is concerned we have to wait for the current tenants to move out before this family can move in.Polly Neate, CEO at housing charity Shelter, said: Hit by budget cuts and a lack of affordable homes, overstretched councils are struggling to keep homeless families within local communities.To put an end to this the government needs to ramp up efforts to build more social housing to give families the chance of a decent and permanent home.

story: In a damning new report, Philip Alston, the UN rapporteur on poverty, said the new flagship benefits system was ruining Brits mental health, finances and work prospects.After a probe into poverty in the UK, he said the Government was in denial about the impact of benefit cuts - and said that leaving the EU could make things even worse.Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily on the working poor, single mothers, the disabled and children, he stormed.He said today: The government could solve this, the money is there, but they choose not to. He blasted ministers as in denial and dont see any problems.After taking a -day tour of the UK, the UN rep looked at Brexit, Universal Credit, cuts to local services and employment.But critics said he shouldnt be focusing on Britain - and should be looking at poverty in third world areas instead.The Australian professor went to Ireland in  too.Tory MPs insisted the plans were a waste of time and money because the UK is one of the richest countries in the world.But today he claimed that one FIFTH of Britain live in poverty - and .million are destitute and cannot afford basics.In a y report he concluded: British compassion for those who are suffering has been replaced by a punitive, mean-spirited, and often callous approach...As the country moves toward Brexit, the Government should adopt policies designed to ensure that the brunt of the resulting economic burden is not borne by its most vulnerable citizens.He was particularly damning about the new flagship benefits system, which roles six payments into one.It is fast falling into Universal Discredit, he said, saying the DWP were more interested in economic savings and sending messages about lestyles than genuinely helping people.Recipients are immediately plunged into further debt and inevitably struggle mightily to survive, he said.Many claimants also feel that they are forced to jump through hoops for the sake of it, fill out pointless job applications for positions that do not match their qualications, and take inappropriate low-paid, temporary work just to avoid debilitating sanctions.One Conservative Party MP with whom I spoke criticised DWP for adopting a military-style command and control approach.But the analysis was rejected by Conservative MPs.Philip Davies said: “If the UN are serious about tackling poverty they might want to go to the Third World. That would be a more valuable use of their time than coming here and grandstanding with some hard-left agenda.”Fellow Tory David Morris added: “Professor Alston has given no methodology to his conclusions. His job means he is permanently hunting on a poverty safari.”Hundreds of Brits have said they are struggling under the new system, and say they have been pushed in to debt for the long wait for payment. One in six Brits are still not getting their first benefits payment on time, new figures revealed this week.Mr Alston blasted the draconian sanctions regime for small errors and said the test and learn approach was treating vulnerable people like guinea pigs and wreak havoc in real peoples’ lives.The digital-focus of Universal Credit was a key part of that, he added, which fails highly vulnerable Brits.The hardest hit are women, children, people with disabilities and pensioners, Mr Alston said.John Dickie, the Director of the Child Poverty Action Groupin Scotland said today: The Rapporteur’s findings should be a wake-up call for government at every level.UK Ministers now need to wake up to the damage being wreaked and end the freeze on working age benefits, scrap the two child limit and fully restore the value of universal credit.But a Government spokesperson said: We completely disagree with this analysis. With this Government’s changes, household incomes have never been higher, income inequality has fallen, the number of children living in workless households is at a record low and there are now one million fewer people living in absolute poverty compared with .Universal Credit is supporting people into work faster, but we are listening to feedback and have made numerous improvements to the system including ensuring . million households will be up to £ better off a year as a result of raising the work allowance.We are absolutely committed to helping people improve their lives while providing the right support for those who need it.

title: 536ad worst year to live plague famine
story: Hard professor Michael McCormick said AD is a prime candidate for the unfortunate accolade of the worst year in the whole of recorded history.At the start of that year, the Middle East, Europe and some parts of Asia faced  months of complete darkness caused by a mysterious fog.It caused snowfall in China, continental-scale crop failure, extreme drought, famine and disease throughout most of the northern hemisphere, reported Daily Mail.The harsh year was caused by a cataclysmic Icelandic eruption, according to scientists.Archaeologist and medieval historian Prof McCormick told Science Magazine the world isnt thought to have recovered until AD - more than  years later.He said: “It was the beginning of one of the worst periods to be alive,not the worst year.”Effects on the climate were so severe that the records tell of “a failure of bread from the years –”.Temperatures in the summer of  fell to between .°C and .°C, making it the coldest decade in the past , years.Historians have long known that the middle of the sixth century was a particularly dark period in what used to be called the Dark Ages.But the source of the mysterious clouds has long been a puzzle.However, McCormick and glaciologist Paul Mayewski at the Climate Change Institute of The University of Maine believe they have figured it out.At a workshop at Hard this week, the team reported that a cataclysmic volcanic eruption in Iceland spewed ash across the Northern Hemisphere early in AD.After that, there were two other massive eruptions in  and .The repeated blows, followed by plague, plunged Europe into economic stagnation that lasted until AD.Volcanic activity is believed to have produced millions of tonnes of ash which spread over vast swathes of the world.Spikes in the ice core for lead proved smelting was taking place to create silver and this coincides with the advent of coin minting which helped revive the economy, according to archaeologist Christopher Loveluck of the University of Nottingham.Researchers found that a century later in AD the silver became the coinage of choice.

title: long cold winter space temperatures nasa
story: Thats the warning from a scientist who fears sunspot activity on the surface of our star has dropped so low that record low temperatures could soon set in.“We see a cooling trend,” says Martin Mlynczak of NASA’s Langley Research Center.“High above Earth’s surface, near the edge of space, our atmosphere is losing heat energy.If current trends continue, it could soon set a Space Age record for cold.”Solar minimum can enhance the effects of space weather, disrupt communications and navigation, and even cause space junk to hang around, NASA said.Mlynczak and his colleagues have recently introduced the Thermosphere Climate Index , which measure the how much heat nitric oxidemolecules are dumping into space.The results come from the SABER instrument onboard NASA’s TIMED satellite, that monitor infrared emissions from carbon dioxideand nitric oxide .By measuring the infrared glow of these molecules, SABER can assess the thermal state of gas at the very top of the atmosphere – a layer researchers call “the thermosphere.”When the thermosphere cools, it shrinks, making the radius of the Earths atmosphere smaller.This means it can delay the natural decay of space junk, resulting in a more cluttered environment around Earth.“Right now, it is very low indeed,” Mlynczak told Space Weather.“SABER is currently measuring  billion Watts of infrared power from NO. That’s  times smaller than we see during more active phases of the solar cycle.”“The thermosphere always cools off during Solar Minimum. It’s one of the most important ways the solar cycle affects our planet,” explains Mlynczak.“We’re not there quite yet,” he said of the record cold, “but it could happen in a matter of months.The most famous example of a prolonged sunspot minimum is the Maunder Minimum, referring to a period around  to  during which sunspots become exceedingly rare.Maunder coincided with the middle part of the Little Ice Age, when Europe and North America experienced colder temperatures - fuelling speculation that the two were connected.However, the prevailing hypothesis for the cause of the Little Ice Age is that it was the result of volcanic action - meaning that a decline in solar activity was not the main cause.

title: worst conditions landlords feral tenants
story: From a bath full of rubbish and an unknown black liquid, to festering toilets, peeling walls and junk-strewn gardens, homeowners have shared these snaps of the wreckage some renters have left behind.One picture shows a bathroom thick with layers of grime and paint peeling from its walls.Another image shows a kitchen stripped bare of any paint, wallpaper of flooring.The pictures have been shared with interior specialist Hillarys, which has launched a competition to find Britains worst tenants from hell.The company invited the nations landlords to upload photos of the worst conditions their tenants have left their homes in, with the most shocking in with a chance of winning £ - cash.

title: statue of unity see space gujart india
story: The colossal Statue of Unity depicts the independence leader Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and was recently unveiled standing at ft – twice the height of the Statue of Liberty which is ft tall.Satellite images have now been released which show it is visible from space.A clear shot of the Statue of Unity in Gujarat was captured from space by the commercial satellite network Planet.The image from the space clearly shows the structure towering over the Narmada River.The statue, which cost £million, has been controversial with questions raised about the price tag as well as its environmental impact.The heads of  villages around the Sardar Saro Dam where it is situated wrote an open letter to India’s nationalist prime minister Narendra Modi criticising the cost and environmental destruction caused by the statue.Modi unveiled the statue of one of the country’s heroes of the independence movement at the end of October and stands in Modi’s home state of Gujarat.In a promotional video, Modi said: This memorial to Sardar [Patel] is going to become a worldwide tourist attraction.See our height, measure this nations height. This is what we want.The Patel statue was built in  months, but not content with one giant statue, Mr Modi has already commissioned another of a warrior king in the state of Maharashtra, set to be ready by .Modi’s prediction the statue would be a huge tourist attraction appears to be coming true, so far.The Times of India reported that , people visited last Saturday.Narmada district Collector R S Ninama, while confirming that , tourists visited Saturday, said the administration was expecting visitor numbers to go even further up.

title: dominos new garlic pizza bread
story: The chain is set to unveil a new garlic bread pizza crust with the best combination of buttery garlic bread and pizza.The pizza giant said in a statement: “It’s the ultimate hybrid pizza garlic bread crust.A quirky pizza edge is not overly new — the hugely popular stuffed cheese option led the way, followed by other brand’s more experimental offerings from meat pie to cheese burger crusts.But outside of pizza, garlic bread is the most ordered menu item and the company expects the new crust to be a big seller.But Dominos said the new dish will not be coming to the UK in the near future.Domino’s Group CEO and Managing Director, Don Meij, said the summer menu launch Down Under was the brand’s biggest-ever initiative.New pizza toppings include BBQ steak and bacon, Korean BBQ steak, succulent garlic chicken and bacon ranch, and chipotle steak.There are three new sauces too as well as a handmade thickshake comprising watermelon and rose water with vanilla ice cream and Turkish delight pieces.Mr Meij said: “This summer Domino’s is looking forward to being a part of the unforgettable spirit of summer and giving Aussies the most delicious and biggest menu ever.Pizza is seriously big business in Australia and competition between outlets is intense.Last year, the Australian arm of the company — which also owns operations in New Zealand, Belgium, France, Japan and Germany — recorded total sales of . billionand a record profit of . million  up  per cent on the previous year.Domino’s sells a whopping two million menu items a week via its online and app ordering services alone.It has invested signicantly in new technologies, from its ordering and preparation systems to self-driving and automated delivery prototypes.This article originally appeared on news.au

title: amber rudd backs theresa may
story: The former Home Secretary had resigned on April  over the Windrush scandal of Commonwealth migrants wrongly deported.But The Sun has learned the PM was “determined” tothe -year-old to the front line to help fend off a Brexiteer coup.Ms Rudd is one of the most impassioned May loyalists on the Tory benches.However, the swt political resurrection also restores Ms Rudd as One Nation Tory moderates’ top candidate for party leaderthe PM is toppled in a confidence vote. That is expected next week.The comeback of the Hastings MP was the most eye-catching move in a swt reshuffle forced on Mrs May after seven resignations in protest at her soft Brexit deal.She replaces Esther McVey, who quit on Thursday after a bitter row with the PM during a five-hour Cabinet meeting on Wednesday to sign off the draft EU plan.The other vacant Cabinet post of Brexit Secretary was filled by Stephen Barclay, who had been a mid-ranking health minister.Ms Rudd’s first act in office was to mount a stinging attack on Mrs May’s seething Brexiteer critics for navel-gazing.Calling on the plotters to think again, Ms Rudd said: “This is not a time for changing our leader, it is a time for pulling together to remember who we are here to serve.“I worry sometimes that my colleagues are too concerned about the Westminster bubble rather than keeping their eye on what our job is.”Extolling Mrs May’s virtues, Ms Rudd added: “I am confident the Prime Minister can survive — I think she’s demonstrated this week her complete commitment to making sure that she serves the people she was elected to do so.”The combative Cabinet minister also praised Mrs May’s Brexit deal as “a really practical response to leaving the European Union” and “the right combination”.Her rapidwas made possible by an official report last month into the Windrush scandal which cleared her of blame.Ms Rudd now faces the titanic task of completing the introduction of Universal Credit, the new all-in-one benefit beset by delays and controversies.Little-known former solicitor Mr Barclay, , is a Brexiteer and May loyalist, and replaces Dominic Raab.But the job in charge of the Department for Exiting the European Union will now only preside over Brexit’s domestic delivery and No Deal preparations.The PM took full charge of the last ten days of EU orce negotiations.Mr Barclay is a close friend of Mrs May’s chief of staff Gavin Barwell, so is “unlikely to resign in a huff like the previous incumbents”, one senior Tory said.Environment Secretary Michael Gove had been offered the top Brexit job by Mrs May on Thursday but turned it down when she refused to let him go back to Brussels to reopen negotiations.Her radio humiliation came as  Conservative MP Greg Hands commented that the PMs cricketing idol was once deliberately run out by a member of his own side - Ian Botham - for the good of the team.Mr Hands wrote on Twitter: Interesting passage from Leo McKinstrys biography of Geoff Boycott when the England team had to run out their own captain for the benefit of the team. England went on to win by  runs.The PM told LBC: The thing about Geoff Boycott is he was absolutely steady, he kept there at the crease, he carried on and relentlessly went about his goal, and I think thats important.But host Nick Ferrari pointed out the England legend had been run out by Jim Love of Yorkshire in his last match.When he quipped Michael Gove might do the same to her premiership, Mrs May hit back: “I think Michael Gove is Scottish.Two troublemakers for No were also brought back into the fold as Mrs May tried to build bridges.Remain-backing EU rebel Stephen Hammond was made a health minister and Brexiteer John Penrose a Northern Ireland minister. Both were previously dumped.Leave campaigner Kwasi Kwarteng was promoted to fill a vacant slot in the Brexit ministry.Labour’s Shadow Minister for the Cabinet Office Jon Trickett called Ms Rudd’s appointment “a desperate choice by a weak Prime Minister”.THERESA May’s draft Brexit deal has split Tories.Here we probe the good and bad in it.End of free movement: The right to set our immigration rules at scheduled end of transition period in December .But EU will in future seek preferential treatment for its citizens infor a trade deal.Fishing: Regaining control of our waters, meaning more stock for our fishermen.But EU will later demand continued access to them infor access to its markets.Security: Continued exchange of DNA, passenger names and fingerprints plus car reg details.PM called it “beyond anything” agreed with any other country.Trade protection: We will be only major economy with zero trade tarfs and quotas.Close alignment to EU rules was necessary to avoid friction at borders and protect Car and aviation industries.Irish backstop: Insurance policy to avoid hard North-South borderwe cannot strike trade deal after transition.Entire UK would stay in customs union with the EU.Backstop exit: EU will have say on when we end backstop.Brexiteers fear we may never ditch customs union.European Court of Justice: During backstop its judges can rule on VAT, state aid, agriculture, customs rules and green policy.Longer transition: Planned December ,  deadline could be extended.It would see us keep paying Brussels.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stephen barclay brexit secretary theresa may twitter memes
story: The MP for North East Cambridgeshire was thrust into the Cabinet yesterday after Michael Gove turned the job down believing it was a poisoned chalice.The PM asked Stephen Barclay, the Leave-voting Health Minister, to take over from Dominic Raab as a leadership crisis swirled around her.But her choice left social media users baffled - with many posting memes asking who Mr Barclay is.One posted a GIF of Steven Coogan as Alan Partridge shrugging with the caption: Stephen Barclay Another shared an image from a goat waiting to be eaten by the T-rex in Jurassic Park, saying: Exclusive footage of new #Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay on his first day at work.One posted a picture of Lenny from The Simpsons nervously sat in Mr Burns office with the caption: Sneak peek of Stephen Barclay on his first day on the job #BrexitSecretary.In a blow to Mr Barclay, Mrs May revealed the -year-old will be the next Brexit Secretary - but he wont be involved in talks with Brussels.STEPHEN Barclay is a Leave-backing MP who won the seat of North East Cambridgeshire in .Since then he has served as a Government whip, Treasury Minister and most recently Health Minister.Outside of politics he served in the military before working as a lawyer for the Financial Services Authority, and then - amusingly - at Barclays.Over the summer he warned that Britain mustnt lower any regulatory standards after Brexit.Mr Barclay takes over the top job from Dominic Raab, who quit earlier this week over Theresa Mays Brexit deal.He becomes the third Brexit Secretary in just four months, after David Davis threw in the towel in July.Hes married and has two kids.The role, previously one of the most powerful in the Cabinet, has been downgraded and will now only involve preparing Britain for our EU exit.His appointment also sent shockwaves through Westminster due to his previous low profile.He said this evening he was delighted to get the role and promised to keep up the momentum to finalise the deal and deliver a Brexit that works for the whole UK.The MP is believed to have landed the job because he is one of the few Brexit-voting ministers left in the Government.Elected to the Commons in , he was a minister in the Treasury for two years before becoming deputy to the Health Secretary in January.Environment Secretary Mr Gove was last night offered the Brexit Secretary job, but refused because he didnt want the responsibility of promoting Mrs Mays deal.The mini reshuffle also saw Amber Rudd brought back into the Cabinet - replacing Esther McVey as Work and Pensions Secretary.

title: lifting weights cardiovascular health advice
story: Both types of exercise improved key measures of cardiovascular health but weightlting was more effective.The muscle-building exercises led to more reductions in body weight and blood pressure and fewer incidences of diabetes.But neither forms of activity improved the amount of artery-clogging fats in the blood, such as cholesterol.It suggests elderly Brits could get more benefit from carrying heavy shopping bags home on the bus than going for a brisk walk.Researchers from St George’s University, in Grenada, analysed the health data and exercise habits of , adults.They found % of those aged  to  engaged in “static” exercises and % in “dynamic” exercises, such as running.The figures for adults aged  and older were % and %, respectively.Engaging in either type of activity lowered cardiovascular risk factors by % to % but the link was strongest in static exercises and in the young.Among the older adults, weightlting lowered blood pressure, body mass index and diabetes but not cholesterol.Activities such as running or cycling only reduced their BMI – but not by as much.Among the younger adults, weightlting lowered body mass index and diabetes only. Dynamic exercises lowered BMI but by a lesser amount.Public Health England suggests  minutes of moderate intensity exercise five days a week and muscle-strengthening exercises twice a week.Study leader Dr Maia Smith said: “Both strength training and aerobic activity appeared to be heart healthy, even in small amounts, at the population level.“However, static activity appeared more beneficial than dynamic, and patients who did both types of physical activity fared better than patients who simply increased the level of one type of activity.“One interesting takeaway was that both static and dynamic activity were almost as popular in older people as younger.“I believe this gives clinicians the opportunity to counsel their older patients that they will fit into the gym or the road race just fine.“The important thing is to make sure they are engaging in physical activity.”The findings were presented at the American College of Cardiology Latin American Conference in Lima, Peru. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ibiza party bars clubs shut up down
story: Ibiza tourist chiefs in Sant Antoni, also known as San Antonio, say they are fed-up with businesses flouting the new rules which require proper soundproofing and adherence to decibel levels, including closing doors and windows after midnight.They say while the situation has got a little better over the last summer, the noise problem is still very bad and inspectors will be going out and about to check which clubs, bars and restaurants are complying.Those that arent will be warned, fined and eventually closed down in a bid to improve the image of the resort and protect residents.The Special Acoustic Protection Zone already affects the party strip known as West End but is now being extended to take in the busy Calle de la Mar which is lined with nightspots.The businesses were all given six months to cut their noise limits and put in soundproofing but many have failed to do so.Those that have say it is unfair that others are still getting away with it.The Mayor of Sant Antoni, Josep Tur said tests were carried out in six streets over three consecutive weeks.While the results were an improvement on , the desirable effect had not been achieved.The council wants to get the decibel levels down to dB but in the majority of cases, the noise level was very bad at more than  decibels.In one particular street, highs of  decibels were recorded every day of the three weeks.Conversation in a restaurant, office, background music or an air conditioning unit at ft is  decibels.Councillor for the interior, Aída Alcaraz said this summer, the Local Police has filed  noise complaints,  of them in the West, against clubs which had left their doors open against the rules.The courts had also dismissed objections from businesses about the new regulations, ruling that the general interest prevails over the economic interests of the entrepreneurs.Sant Antoni council says many people have blamed the noise levels on the thousands of tourists as they leave pubs and clubs at closing time but this is not the case.Their tests had shown the noise was consistently bad at any time in the evening, not necessarily at throwing out time.

title: move junk food health advice obesity
story: They claim placing chocolate, crisps and doughnuts in high-profile areas encourages people to buy more and is fuelling the obesity crisis.But critics warn it will not be long before junk food is treated like fags and porn mags and only sold over the counter or from top shelves.The Obesity Health Alliance, which represents charities and medical groups, found % of food and drink in these areas was high in fat, sugar or salt.And their survey of Asda, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Tesco stores revealed an average of just % was healthier fruit and vegetables.Public Health England guidelines suggest eating five portions of fruit and veg a day, which should make up over a third of our diet.More than one in three children leaves primary school too fat, increasing their risk of cancer, type- diabetes, and heart disease in later le.The Government is expected to launch a consultation on the promotion and placement of junk food as part of its Childhood Obesity Strategy.Caroline Cerny, from the Obesity Health Alliance, said: “Where products are located in shops influences how likely we are to purchase them.“Sugary treats prominently displayed at checkouts or store entrances will be highly tempting to anyone, but especially children who will then likely pester their parents to buy them.“Action is needed to create healthier environments for families across the country.“Some supermarkets seem to be taking positive steps to limit where they promote unhealthy food but we need a level playing field.“The OHA is calling on Government to restrict the placement of unhealthy food and drinks in high profile locations in supermarkets to help families make healthier choices when shopping”.Bryony Sinclair, from the World Cancer Research Fund, said: “Displaying sugary food and drinks in prominent positions is unacceptable.“These powerful promotions tempt shoppers to make unhealthy last-minute decisions.“Many of these food and drinks contain more sugar than the daily recommended amount for a young child.“Eating too much sugar can lead to weight gain, and being overweight or obese increases the risk of  dferent types of cancer.“Governments need to introduce policies that prevent supermarkets from promoting unhealthy food and drinks in prominent positions, in order to help create environments that support healthier choices.”Christopher Snowdon, from the Institute of Economic Affairs, said: “People want to buy a iety of goods in a supermarket and popular items should be conveniently placed.“It won’t be long before Mars Bars are treated like cigarettes, hidden behind screens and only available to buy over the counter.“And pizzas will be treated like porn mags, placed on the top shelf, out of reach and out of sight of ‘vulnerable’ youngsters.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexiteers secret plot to force theresa may to change her brexit deal
story: Micheal Gove will lead Cabinet ministers Andrea Leadsom, Liam Fox, Penny Mordaunt and Chris Grayling to try and make the PM seal more promises on a future trade deal.The pivotal Environment Secretary was seen to have held Mrs Mays political fate in his hands as he agonised for  hours over quitting - but decided to stay to try and tweak the deal.The Pizza Plotters will hold talks this weekend and early next week to try and pin down a Canada-style trade deal from the EU.The news comes as The Sun revealed that Brexiteer rebels are still eleven letters short of forcing a leadership contest in Mrs May.Tory critics of the Prime Minister were desperately scrabbling to get the crucial  letters needed to spark the ballot - but sources confirmed they were still stuck at .Tory Chairman Brandon Lewis launched a full-scale defence of the Prime Minister, saying she was absolutely the right person to lead our country.Urging grumbling MPs who could be considering sending a letter in to try and topple her to think again, he told Radio  this morning that her fortitude, determination and passion for delivering for our country meant they should hold off at such a crucial point for Britain.He went on: We are right at the crux point for negotiating, the most important deal since the Second World War.The PM is absolutely right to focus on getting the right deal for the United Kingdom.And another May loyalist, Alan Duncan also went out to fight for her, urging rebels to stop, think and step back from the brink.He said that Pizza Plotters were living a fantasythey thought they could force more changes from the EU.The prime minister has no other alternative she can deliver, he stressed.The five Pizza Plotters decided to stay in Government as they thought they would have more influence there, Cabinet sources told The Sun last night.But Mr Gove and the others have now given up hope of winning changes to the controversial Irish backstop, that could keep the UK in a customs union for years.The Cabinet source said: “May has made clear that she won’t allow the backstop to be unpicked, so Michael and the others will now wait to seeit falls at the meaningful vote.“But the political declaration on the future trade deal can be improved, as that’s still being negotiated right up to the summit. That’s where they feel they can have real effect now.”But The Sun can also reveal that Mr Gove told the PM her soft Brexit deal will be rejected by the Commons in a crucial showdown meaningful vote next month when he turned down her offer of Brexit Secretary on Thursday.NEXT WEEKEND: EU leaders have emergency summit to seal off the draft Brexit dealNEXT MONTH: MPs have to vote through the final deal, but theres a huge chance it might not pass at all. POSSIBLE OUTCOMES:  GOT a story  Ring The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or email exclusive@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog owners leave bins kicked out home
story: The blonde and brown pooches were in a cage next to black bin bags, old blankets and unwanted clothes in Barstow, Calornia.Allen Boartfield, a volunteer with Dream Fetchers: Project Rescue, woke up to a distressing call that two dogs were spotted on a street corner on November .The dogs were rushed to the Camino Pet Hospital in Irvine, Calornia where they are being treated.The blonde dog has been named Catch and the brown dog has been named Treasure.Hedy Herold, the rescue coordinator for the hospital, said the pups were very distressed when they arrived.She told The Dodo: “Catch and Treasure came to us with visibly shaken spirits and broken hearts.“Treasure was so matted that she couldnt move without pain and she was snapping at our technicians who wanted to help her.”The two dogs are inseparable and have stayed huddled together, but Catch had to be temporarily separated after catching a cold.When Boartfield first rescued the pups he said they were very distressed.He told The Dodo: “They were both extremely scared. Treasure got used to me fairly quickly, but Catch never did.“Catch is very attached to Treasure. So attached that, when I moved Treasure into another kennel, even though Catch was very scared still, he ran across my lap to be in the same kennel as Treasure.”Catch, the blonde pooch, even nipped Boartfield on the hands a few times out of fear.Staff say Treasure has developed her outgoing personality and is almost recovered from her traumatic experience.However, Catch is still very shy and afraid of people and other dogs.It is unclearthe owners has been reported to the police orthere is an investigation underway.

title: pm should stand down after brexit james forsyth
story: A sizeable number of her own MPs will vote against it and her Northern Irish allies, the DUP, will reject it too.EvenMrs May could persuade  Labour MPs to back her, an optimistic assumption, that still would not be enough to get this over the line.So what can she do to change the dynamic  Well, she needs to try to separate the question of what the country should DO NOW from how she has handled Brexit since entering Downing Street.Mrs May has made some huge mistakes in her handling of Britain’s departure from the EU. There has been little preparation made for leaving without a deal, weakening the UK’s negotiating hand and sending a message to the EU that we’ll never walk away.She triggered Article  without knowing what she wanted, then wasted months and months of valuable negotiating time in internal discussions. She signed up to a joint report on the Irish border without telling her Cabinet how that would limit the UK’s options and end up shaping the entire negotiations.Even in recent weeks, she has made mistakes — making it patently obvious to the EU how much of a hurry she was in to get a deal and not letting her own Brexit Secretary seehe could winkle any concessions out of the EU. Given all this, it is not surprising that so many Brexiteers want to vote down her deal.But the question of how Mrs May has handled Brexit so far is NOT THE SAME as the issue of what Parliament should do given where we are now. There is ONLY ONE WAY for Mrs May to break this link.She should say that as soon as the withdrawal legislation is through the Commons, she will stand down as Prime Minister.  This would enable MPs to vote for the deal without that being an endorsement of her handling of Brexit or an invitation for her to negotiate the next stage of Brexit, the UK EU trade deal.One Cabinet minister tells me the PM is now an impediment to this deal passing. Her announcing her departure would make it easier for MPs to vote for the deal.Mrs May’s allies dismiss this idea out of hand. But she needs to do somethingshe is not to see her deal voted down, increasing — as she herself says — the chances of either no deal or no Brexit, both of which would be bad for the country.In Wednesday’s marathon Cabinet meeting, one of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox’s arguments for accepting the deal was that it would be possible for the UK to claw things back in the second half, the actual UK EU trade negotiations.But as any football fan will tell you, a team trailing badly at half-time doesn’t change things round by simply sending the same team in the same formation back on to the pitch.Would Liverpool have come back from - down to win the Champions League in they hadn’t changed anything at the interval  No.  If things really are to be dferent in the second half of these talks, then the UK will need new leadership.Now the problem is that some of these arrangements create an ongoing obligation under international law. So, getting out of all of them unilaterally would involve breaking international law. This would, arguably, be in breach of the ministerial code which requires them to “comply with the law”.But, I understand, it was pointed out at the meeting that the PMhas the power to suspend the ministerial code when necessary.This means the Government could simply get out of the backstop, then dare the EU to take it to court“LOYALTY is a two-way street,” one Cabinet minister told me after Dominic Raab resigned. This minister pointed out that Raab had been cut out of the negotiations so couldn’t be expected to go along with the result of them.David Davis resigned as Brexit Secretary because his advice was ignored. Michael Gove wouldn’t take the job because it came with no real power.Mrs May has appointed a new Brexit Secretary, Steve Barclay. But No are saying he will only be responsible for no-deal planning and the Parliamentary side of the job. He won’t be negotiating.He will also, as a Brexiteer, be sent out to defend this deal. He will be a “flak jacket to go out on TV”, one Leaver tells me.SPECULATION is swirling in Westminster about whether Mrs May will face a vote of no confidence or not in the next week.Several Cabinet Ministers are resigned to a vote happening. Others worry that the vote is ill-timed, that in going for her now the plotters won’t win but will instead ensure she stays on as Prime Minister for another  months and takes charge of the UK EU trade negotiations.A minister complains: “If we strike and miss now, we’ll be shackled to a corpse for a year and Corbyn really will get in.” Butthe rebels do get their  letters, Mrs May might have a harder time in the confidence vote than expected – though she will still win it.Several ministers admit that, in the privacy of the ballot box, they will vote against her.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal ruthless planning sun says opinion
story: But as the new boss of No Deal planning, he may have the most important job in Government.Onlywe’re ready for a clean break from Brussels is there a chance that the Prime Minister’s dodgy deal might be improved — and get through Parliament.Over the past two years of circuitous negotiations, the one lesson has been that the European Union understands only the most brutal, blunt language.British negotiators have tried the give-and-take compromise approach and the only result has been their pockets being turned out before they’ve got back on the Eurostar.We must now be clear that we are not just prepared to leave without a deal but will embrace doing so. That means Mr Barclay needs to get our ports, our airports, our security services and our customs authorities ready for March .Chancellor Philip Hammond must be clear, too, that he will use the £billion earmarked for the “orce bill” for a massive programme of infrastructure spending and tax cuts that will supercharge the economy. We must be bold.Theresa May has been clear that this is a “draft” deal. In truth Brussels will not change a single word unless we show them that we’re not scared of building a future outside the EU.The sorry deal we have is the direct result of unimaginative civil servants who viewed the vote to leave — the largest democratic mandate this country has ever seen — not as an opportunity to build a better future but as a damage-limitation exercise.It is telling that the PM, with remarkable resilience, has to do her own cheerleading. Where are all those in the Cabinet who back the deal  Why aren’t they on the TV and the radio It’s hard to shake the feeling that some still around the table are thinking too much about their career prospects at this vital time, hoping nobody will remember their silence.We hope the Brexiteers in the Cabinet, sidelined for too long, DO redraw this plan. They are, after all, now armed with the fact that as it stands it will struggle to get through Parliament. We hope that the Prime Minister WILL tell the EU they need to bend.But they will only listenwe ready ourselves to walk away and be ruthless.The PM’s unofficial deputy told the Cabinet this week not to get too hung up on the exit mechanism, that parliament could always find a way.It was pointed out that,needed, we could suspend the Ministerial Code and break international lawthe national interest required it.We shouldn’t take such a step lightly.But we are in extraordinary times, and perhaps only extraordinary action will do.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexiteers keep up pressure on pms leadership and serfdom brexit deal
story: Amid the ongoing turmoil, Mid-Bedfordshire MP Nadine Dorries told Sky News she would not be surprisedthe number of letters of no confidence in Mrs May had already met the threshold of  needed to trigger a vote on the prime ministers leadership.Predicting fellow MPs will "see things moving on Monday", Ms Dorries suggested  Committee chair Sir Graham Brady - who would organise any confidence vote in the prime minister - would soon be double-checking whether MPs had lost faith in Mrs May.If a vote does occur next week, Ms Dorries predicted many Tory MPs would not want to give the prime minister a years protection from another challenge by voting in favour of her leadership. Under Conservative Party rules,a leader survives a confidence vote they cannot be challenged again for another  months.With the DUP - the Tories Northern Irish allies who prop up Mrs Mays minority government at Westminster - among the strongest critics of the draft Brexit deal, Ms Dorries predicted voters could soon be asked to go to the polls. She said: "If the DUP walk away we have no majority and therefore, by default, we would be going into a general election with Theresa May leading us into that election."Now, you need half of the Conservative Party to vote not with her for a vote of no confidence."But I think you would find % of the Conservative Party MPs -not more - who do not want the scenario of having a general election unplanned and with Theresa May leading us into that general election."Ms Dorries added: "MPs will think to themselves, If I vote to keep the prime minister in place shes going to be there for the next  months when anything could happen, is that what I want  And I think most MPs will vote no." She also defended her description of the Brexit deal as leaving the UK as "slaves" to the EU."I would call us a vassal state, an empty state, Id call it serfdom, its appalling," Ms Dorries said."Its actually beyond almost belief Number  - although theyre spinning like mad - think they can sell this to the country. They cant, people can see right through it."The Brexiteer also told Mrs May her draft agreement with Brussels "doesnt stand a cat in hells chance of getting through parliament". There are  Tory MPs who have publicly declared, or confirmed to Sky News, they have submitted a letter of no confidence in the prime minister.

title: frenetic efforts to save may and her brexit plan
story: It is unclear whether Number s frenetic efforts this weekend are intended to prevent the number of letters getting to , or to ensure the prime minister can get the backing of the  Tory MPs she would need to win a confidence vote - either way, the fight is on.Government whips were ordered to stay in Westminster to exert coordinated pressure on MPs against submitting letters of no confidence. Theresa May herself held a conference call with hundreds of constituency party chairs to persuade them to roll-in behind her.As well as using all the levers of the party machinery available to affect the political arithmetic, there also appears to be an attempt to win over public sympathy.In an interview with the Daily Mail, the prime minister recounts the support and loyalty of her husband Philip, who she says feels the pain of the personal abuse she receives more than she does.She describes him pouring her a whisky after the five-hour long cabinet meeting on Wednesday, and being so enraged by the interviews with rebels being re-played on the news that he switched off the television.
