When we got there he wanted a chocolate muffin and a drink so we arrived and he looked a bit like a mad scientist with chocolate on his face!ldquoThe second time we had been at a party before it and he had [eaten] a blue lsquoSlushyrsquo.ldquoThe casting team said they liked the fact he was clearly a real boy and not too prim and proper so it worked for him in the end.Cockenzie Primary School pupil Ethan who attends Pauline Quirk Academy of Performing Arts in Edinburgh, has had small parts in the past, appearing in a McDonaldrsquos advert and short films, but this is his first big role.Yvonne said: ldquoI studied acting when I was younger and when I had my children things were put on a backburner. I encouraged the children to act, I think it is good for their confidence andthey enjoy it then it can be a great benefit.News of Ethanrsquos role was kept quiet until last Friday, when his agent posted a photograph of the youngster onset with former M.I. High cast member Josh Haynes, who is playing Mack.Molly and Mack is on CBeebies at .pm, Monday to Friday.

title: second-shipment-of-supplies-blasts-off-for-space-station
story: Northrop Grumman launched its Antares rocket from Wallops Island before dawn, delighting chilly early-bird observers along the Atlantic coast.ldquoWhat an outstanding launch, said Nasarsquos deputy space station programme manager Joel Montalbano.The Russian Space Agency launched its own load of supplies to the International Space Station on Friday, just  hours earlier.The US delivery will arrive at the orbiting lab on Monday, a day after the Russian shipment.LIFTOFF! @northropgrummanrsquos #Antares rocket just launched from @NASA_Wallops in Virginia. Heading to @Space_Station, the #Cygnus cargo vehicle will deliver about , pounds of @ISS_Research and cargo. Watch as it continues its journey into space: https:t.co mzKWuDsTi pic vpUXFYvKSmdash NASANovember , Among the ,lb of goods inside the Cygnus capsule are ice cream and fresh fruit for the three space station residents, and a D printer that recycles old plastic into new parts.Thanksgiving turkey dinners mdash rehydratable, of course mdash are already aboard the -mile-high outpost. The space station is currently home to an American, a German and a Russian.There is another big event coming up ndash the ISS marks its th year in orbit on Tuesday. The first section launched on November   from Kazakhstan.ldquoAs we celebrate  years of the International Space Station, Mr Montalbano said, ldquoone of the coolest things is the co-operation we have across the globe. To me, itrsquos been a huge success.Russiarsquos Progress cargo craft blasted off on its way to the station today at :pm ET. It will arrive at the orbital lab Sunday with about , pounds supplies and goodies for the crew. https:t.co dtUGpSUG pic CxuByrSIJmdash Intl. Space StationNovember , This Cygnus is named the SS John Young to honour the famous astronaut who walked on the moon and commanded the first space shuttle flight. He died in January.It is the first commercial cargo ship to bear Northrop Grummanrsquos name. The firm acquired Orbital ATK in June. SpaceX is Nasarsquos other commercial shipper for the space station.Experiments also are going up to observe how cement solidies in weightlessness, among other things.Take a look at our NG- mission page here to learn more about #Antares and what #Cygnus will be carrying to @Space_Station https:t.co PxrnKXmdash Northrop GrummanNovember , There is also medical, spacesuit and other equipment to replace items that never made it to orbit last month because of a Russian rocket failure. The two men who were riding the rocket survived their emergency landing.Three other astronauts are set to launch from Kazakhstan on December .

title: engineer-dad-from-glasgow-captures-stunning-images-of-posing-highland-stag-on-day-out
story: Steve Green, , was on a road trip with his daughter Georgia, , last week when the pair came across the majestic creature.The engineer had a day off last Thursdayand decided to take a trip up to Glen Etive in the Highlands.The area is around  miles from Glasgow and is known for its thriving wild deer population.Dad Steve spotted the stag with a herd of around  deer but managed to get close enough to snap the amazing pictures.Steve said: "Ive lived in Glasgow for  years but never even up that way."I had a day off work and decided to take a trip."We wanted to take the Glen Coe chairlt but it was closed so we took a drive along to Glen Etive - its absolutely stunning."We just came to the corner of a bend and then there was one big stag with about  deer."Steve had to be sure to keep his distance from the stag which was protecting its herd but admitted: "Ive never been that close to a stag before."We just felt we got very lucky and we will remember it for a long time - it might never happen again."

title: neil-oliver-on-his-british-isles-in-100-places-tour-and-why-nicola-sturgeon-is-the-kirk-elder
story: I wonder how Oliver has achieved this longevity in a business that dumps presenters like plastic in the sea  Andtherersquos a sense that Churchillrsquos borrowed quote "Those who fail to learn from history are condemned to repeat it" rings as true as a church bell, surely the opposite should apply  Given Oliver knows an awful lot about history and archaeology, could TV survival be down to the fact hersquos learned what not to do We meet at the Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, near where he lives with his we and three children. Oliver looks way younger than  years on this planet would suggest, and is relaxed, yet on the clock, given one of his brood has to picked up from school in an hour.He certainly has the energy to undertake a tour of the great theatre halls of the land with his new show, telling of the British Isles in  Places, Glasgow this week which expands upon the detail in his new book of the same title. But his is all new to him  ldquoIrsquove spoken in public before, at literary festivals, but not night after night, he says. ldquoI only get a couple of days off during the months and itrsquos quite intense and nerve wracking. Having said that, itrsquos a fascinating and very dferent way of seeing a country. And it makes you question the notion of what a country is. Once you interrogate this notion you realise the audience in the North East [of England], for example, is a very dferent tribe from those in the South."You get this throughout Scotland as well. The iety of what you find leaves you confused. At times you donrsquot know where you are.But there is a commonality, I ask. Arent we all in the same boat ndash one which seems to be sinking  He doesnrsquot think so. ldquoWersquove been through everything, from invasion to natural disaster to famine to religious fundamentalism, he says. ldquoWersquove been through civil war, wars of independence, the industrial revolution, two world wars. All of this has unfolded in the same tapestry. This is just a period in history. In a  years there will be dferent issues and a dferent set of politics.Thatrsquos a comfort. Sort of. But meantime, what do we do about Brexit, Neil  ldquoI donrsquot want to deal in that, he says, placing his coffee cup down with a slightly emphatic clump, suggesting hersquos learned to avoid controversy. ldquoIrsquom careful not to offer an opinion on any of that. My tour aim is to put an arm around the shoulder of someone I care about, which is this archipelago. Itrsquos a love letter to the British Isles, a spectacular place which has looked after me, and now itrsquos my turn to look after him ndash or her.He offers a thought: ldquoThe motto of the Isle of Man, lsquoWhichever way you throw me I will standrsquo, the three legged symbol, I think thatrsquos a great motto for people to live by.Thatrsquos easy to say, but wersquore facing confusion, polarisation of politics, right-wing extremism. You must be afraid of the isions politics has produced and the invective that comes with it  It seems everyone wants to be angry.ldquoIrsquom sick of politics, he admits. ldquoIrsquom completely disenchanted with all of it. Politicians lack so much knowledge. If Irsquom honest, I donrsquot think therersquos a politician out there worth listening to, of any creed or colour. I donrsquot have any truck with any of them. Irsquom just looking away at the moment while they do what they do, which is self-aggrandizing and performing their Punch and Judy nonsense. I cannot be bothered with it.He adds: ldquoI was in that arena vaguely for a while on account of a few opinions I was invited to give.He certainly was. Oliver incurred the wrath of the Nationalists back in  when he declared independence for Scotland a "dead dog."But does he now regret becoming involved in the independence debate He pauses for thought. ldquoNo, I think itrsquos important to say what you think is true. But I donrsquot like the atmosphere at the moment whereby you canrsquot say what you think. If you are not pleasing the social media mob you are silenced or destroyed. I was asked some questions and I gave an honest answer.Oliver rejects the offer of half a sconeand instead sips at his coffee cup. ldquoHow it really started for me was when I was being interviewed for Bannockburn  [his TV show] and a journalist asked me about the referendum. ldquoI remember saying, lsquoA referendum is like going shopping for food when yoursquore hungry.rsquo You donrsquot want to be making snap decisions.Because you come away with a packet of Hobnobs and a jar of Nutella  ldquoExactly. I donrsquot think we should have referendums to decide which side of the road we should drive on, never mind kicking the ball back to the general population to determine a nationrsquos destiny. Thatrsquos why we have political democracy, whereby we employ hundreds of people to read tedious paperwork, shout and bawl at each other in a room for as long as it takes. Thatrsquos why these -odd people have a job.He becomes more animated. ldquoReferendums are a bad idea. After the Scottish referendum there were immediate cries for another one. lsquoThat disnae countrsquo. Now therersquos been Europe. And that was seen to be wrong. And so you claim for another one. What do you do  Go for best of three  Or best of five Oliver smiles. ldquoIrsquove never been a card-carrying member of a political party. I used to scoff at university friends who were. In the same way I couldnrsquot understand why anyone would get excited about football. Irsquom not minded that way.Yet, but he is minded to recognise how politics overlaps into culture and issues of identity, which he loves to wax lyrical about on his TV shows. But there are those who donrsquot countenance his passion for explaining the likes of Iona and the coming of Christianity. Some, such as Professor Tom Devine, see Oliver as an irritant.The historian once attacked the fact Oliver had been asked to front a History of Scotland ndash given he didnrsquot have a degree in history.Oliver didnrsquot take Devinersquos comment laying down however, describing the historian as being like of the old grumps from The Muppets.More recently, Oliver got it in the neck when appointed president of the National Trust for Scotland, and many Nationalists demanded his removal, which seemed odd given the TV presenterrsquos passion for this space we live in.But the writer presenter took it on broad shoulders. Did his personal history prepare him for the future stre  Seems so. Hersquos used to adjustment. ldquoI was born in a council flat in Renfrew, my dad moved to Ayr to work [he was a commission salesman] and then to Dumfries. The family was ldquocomfortable, he says. It certainly wasnrsquot an Angelarsquos Ashes set in Scotland storyline. They even managed a holiday to Spain once.Yet, the man who would go on to explain the Picts and Vikings and anacyclosis to uswasnrsquot top of the class at school. ldquoI was in the upper half but I wasnrsquot so great at maths and science so I focused on English and history, which I was quite good at.Oliver was blessed with encouraging parents who most likely were baffled why their son wanted to study archaeology, University I fell in love with the prospectus given it rarely leads to a career. ldquoI did work as an excavator for a few years going on digs, he recalls. ldquoIt was fun, but there was no money in it. And during the winters it became a bit grim.One Friday afternoon he was excavating the Roman Road in Greenock, and on the Monday he was covering a peace protest in Lockerbie for the local newspaper. Why the switch to journalism ldquoI liked the idea of journalism because it was essentially noseyness about people, he explains, grinning. ldquoItrsquos a bit like archaeology in that itrsquos the chance to poke through the rubbish, to find out what people were doing and why. Instinctively, I want to know who, what, where, why and when.Journalism has been as important to his current career, he says, as his time spent scraping dirt with a big spoon. ldquoWhen Irsquove been cast in the likes of Coast as a presenter it helped me get something out of people. And this Magpie-like work taught me how to become engrossed in a subject for a day then drop it, and move onto something .The curious mind continued to search for the next adventure and in  he joined a BT internet company. ldquoI thought that may be my future. I was also fascinated to learn how it had evolved, largely financed by the US military, who wanted to knowcomputers could survive after a nuclear attack. And so they hired these hippies to find out. And then I wondered what do we do with it  What are the consequences of it He answers his own question: ldquoItrsquos created titans such as Mark Zuckerberg, and Amazon, Google and Pay Pal. He adds in soft, serious voice, ldquoNow, Zuckerberg is almost at the point he has more power than Putin, without the missiles.While working for the internet company, Oliver decided to set off for Zululand.ldquoI had met up with my close pal from university Tony Pollard one day in the Granary Bar in Glasgowrsquos Shawlands and we came up with the idea of going to Zululand to make a film [which became the BBCrsquos  documentary, Two Men In A Trench].Boldness has to be part of the reason for Oliverrsquos success. He had a good job, with a good salary, a car and an Amex account. ldquoBut I didnrsquot have a mortgage. I wasnrsquot married. I could take a chance. And I knew I had had experience. When the TV job ran out Irsquod do something .Does the job flipping suggest a malcontent  ldquoNo, when I was at BT I figured Irsquod give it a couple of years, he says with a wee hint of umbrage in his voice for me having suggested such a thing. ldquoAnd we made the film really because we wanted to go to South Africa. The voice warms again: ldquoArchaeology was my first love and we met again. It was like Friends Reunited. And wersquove been together ever since.Hersquos a television natural. But did he always feel confident speaking to the camera  ldquoYes. Irsquove always had a good memory and Irsquom lucky in that I can remember  words in the right order, he says, grinning. ldquoTalking to the camera is not a natural thing to do. Itrsquos like a golf swing. But some people can do it. And I enjoyed being with these like-minded people. It was quite collegiate. I loved it from the get-go.Oliver landed on the box at the right time. ldquoI was   when television began to happen for me. I had few delusions about my own reality. Irsquod been in a few dferent jobs, had the rougher edges knocked off by le experience. Irsquod filled shelves at Presto supermarket while eating the Mars Bars. Irsquod worked on an MS till. He adds, with a wry smile, ldquoIrsquod been dumped often enough by women.Women. Yes, now hersquos married to one. And history taught him he should incorporate this woman into his future. Oliver met his future we Trudi when he was at university. ldquoI was in third year at the time, the president of the archaeology society and she was in first year, and she came in to join. I made a bee-line for her when she walked in the door.He grins. ldquoI donrsquot think she was as impressed by me as I was by her.She must have liked him a little because the pair were together for seven years. ldquoAnd it just sort of fizzled out. Then, years later, I met her wee brother Johnny and we swapped numbers and a few months after that I was back in touch with Trudi. It was asIrsquod seen her the day before.He reflects: ldquoThatrsquos another great thing about my le. Whatever happens, I know Irsquom with someone who remembers me when I was  and a silly arse. She remembers me when I had all sorts of archaeology student affectations, all patchouli oil and cheese cloth shirts. We can remember the teenagers we were.Oliver reveals he had the long hair back in the day. He didnrsquot create the soft Tarzan look for telly. He has just never bothered to have it cut. And it works for him, gives him a USP, although watching him on TV with the wind blasting into his face as he stands on a clf edge he does have to brush it away from his mouth a little too often but, I suppose, a kirby grip or a hair scrunchy would wreck the image.He laughs. ldquoIrsquove been holding out for the Head and Shoulders contract for  years but itrsquos never happened.Therersquos a calm about Oliver, even though he does become animated when he talks about the politics he says he wants nothing to do with. And he clearly loves his le, beaming at the delights of a career which allows him to take his family adventuring in the likes of Australia and New Zealand while filming Coast. Yet with three children hersquos not immune to worry, about the impact of social media, for example. ldquoPeople can have , friends, but ironically they have never been more isolated and lonelier. People go to Facebook ndash I donrsquot ndash hoping to see other people in this clearing in the forest who are equally lonely.Hersquos happy however, very happy. ldquoThe thing I most love these days is writing. I wrote as a student, as a journalist and then in TV with scripts. Irsquove written ten books or so and itrsquos something Irsquoll be able to do.And now hersquos making live appearances. ldquoIrsquove sort of blundered into them. Irsquom out there talking about our world, like Simon Reeve and Dan Snow. Maybe I can do this every year. Why not So the world will be all right, Neil  We need you to tell us it will be. ldquoWe tend to think this is a modern concern, but perhaps Stonehenge and Avebury are partly expressions of feeling the same concerns, people feeling they are little specks in the great scheme of things and wanting to be heard, to make a mark.He grins, reassuringly. ldquoWersquoll be fine, but I wonrsquot beI donrsquot do this school pick-up in time.Neil Oliver ndash The Story of the British Isles in  Places, the Theatre Royal, Glasgow, November .

title: fidelma-cook-cesar-the-existential-dog-with-apologies-to-the-original-existential-cat
story: Je suis un existentialist.I arrived here exactly four years ago, dragged from my family in the Pas de Calais ndash abandoned in the home of the foreigner.She spoke in a devil tongue and her French was excruciating to my aristocratic ear.I was called Jazzybefore, and now I was to be Ceacutesar. Pretentious  Elle  Le sigh.I sat in my open cage. She sat on a step watching me. I held her eye stood, crouched slowly, and peed over the pathetic baby blanket shersquod given me along with a soft toy.The toy was already shredded.A shocked cry came from her. I smiled. Inside. She needed to be trained early.I bit and bit her as she took me outside. It had been dark when I arrived but now I could see the full horror.Merde.Nothing but green and sky. No pavements. No sound but those flying turds called birds.Hey, I screamed. Irsquom showbiz. My family are all champions sweetie. We donrsquot do country.We toss and prance around the show rings of Europe. My mama and papa are queen and king of the circuit.Get me out of this sodding hellhole and back to my destiny.Stupid woman thought I was so cute yelping at the world and her.Irsquom serious here, I screamed again, biting her ankles for emphasis. Donrsquot bury me alive. Irsquom a future star ndash I need my stage my public ndash help me, help me, anyone.Nobody came.Not for me. For her ndash initially, yes. They looked in disbelief at the chunks Irsquod taken from her legs and hands and then back at me.Oui  I turned my head winsomely sideways, tossing my blond hair from my eyes, indicating her lies. I kept my wrath for her and her alone.She wore boots always after that and covered her legs and arms.She got me a trainer who took me around markets and towns where at least I was recognised for the player I was. They stopped and cooed over my beauty ndash of course I had a weekly groomer ndash and took pictures to show on Instagram.The foreigner hovered in the background muttering to the trainer about watching he doesnrsquot bite donrsquot let that child near him and often said a word beginning with F.Too dull. I took to evacuating all in the car heading home just to watch her sob. She compared me often to a Portia ndash a sap of an Afghan as far as I could see.One night as she stared at the stars I heard something and jumped. She didnrsquot. I wonrsquot reiterate her hospital stay, her re-education etc.I went to kennels and Trudi. Meanwhile, her friends told her to get rid of me. She got rid of them.Then the Italians came to look after both of us. I loved them. They ran and played with me while she sat in a wheelchair.They called me emperor and mi amore. Then they left.People, who used to come around, stopped. They always thought she was insane getting me in the first place. She was.But I was hers, and God help me, she was mine.I gave her a break because I was by now into Sartre. I understood the nothingness of it all and my place in a meaningless universe.She told me she was one at . Apparently a black polo neck is de rigeur. I donrsquot wear clothes butI didhellip.Irsquom now allowed to roam alone outside my compound but I go inside to chase the cars.Irsquom not as moody as I was but Irsquom aware Irsquove become a bit needy. I sit next to her on the sofa and watch the soaps she loves.Instead of biting I just nibble her. Through the night I bark at anything that moves outside ndash more for myself, to prove Irsquom alive, not buried alive.In between I dream. I dream of the le that should have been mine. Crufts. Champion of champions.Unlike other dogs ndash God I hate that word ndash I donrsquot twitch in my sleep ndash I extend my exquisite legs.We, the foreigner et moi, have settled into a routine. I speak English now and I understand her tortured French. She swears a lot, in both languages.I suppose shersquos the Simone de Beauvoir to my Sartre. Compliant in awe of my superior presence while quietly re-telling, rewriting the story.I am dependent on her. I have finally accepted this. She is all Irsquove got andanything happens to her then I am truly buggered.She worries about this too given all thatrsquos happened but for now we live in the moment and Irsquom careful not to trip her up.But Irsquom bored. She is bored. We sigh together and have another oven chip.Existentialists do that.

title: real-slice-of-italy-baked-pizza-al-taglio-glasgow-reviewed-by-ron-mackenna
story: GlasgowOK, they donrsquot have the pizza that our kids always used to have in Italy. That would be the wurstel and patatine or hot dog and chips. Hey, donrsquot laugh itrsquos hugely popular over there. But they do have potato and rosemary. So we immediately order four slices of what is a family favourite.Itrsquos usually the last piece of Italian food we eat in Italy every summer as we stop off at one of the once-great-now-sadly-not-so-good Autogrills that line the autostrade before the culinary bleakness of Switzerland.We order tonight, too, a few squares of Calabrian sausage and onion a prosciutto, straciatella and fig jam pear and gorgonzola.Delight is probably the best way to describe our first reaction to a pizza al taglio take-away-with-seats opening in Glasgowrsquos east end. On Duke Street, in fact, just opposite Tennents Brewery.Surprise is probably our second reaction. Why  Witness this. We gaze at the plump, freshly-baked, attractive-looking squares seductively laid out on racks at the counter. We ooh and ahh over which of the many exotic toppings wersquore going to have. We order what we want.Then we gape when it turns out those squares have hard-to-notice cuts on them and actually theyrsquore not squares at all but subided into long rather thin rectangles.Aah, theyrsquore half the size then of those that are usually served at al taglio ndash or by-the-slice places ndash in rural Italy where a euro a slice of margherita is still possible.Part of the joy of eating there is simply to have a huge, slobbery, delicious piece of warm baked goodness in the hand. Hold hard though. Allowance has to be made here for the amount of exotic toppings, the transporting across borders, Glasgow prices and, er novelty.And in all fairness pizza al taglio is very expensive in places like Romersquos Pizzarium Di Bonci which often tops the Italian Gambero Rosso guide. Although Baked here is based on Romersquos fashionable al taglio joints, much humbler al taglio is available theand breadth of the country in little bakers who do nothing  but turn out trays of delicious, crusty, creamy pizza that are usually bought by weight.The best Irsquove ever had was much further north in Varese, maybe  years ago. I can still taste its amazing creaminess, but I remember too as a kid being with my Nonna in a small town in Molise where we arrived at an al taglio just as the pizza margherita tray came out the oven. We stood and ate them from greaseproof paper right away.Anyway, whatrsquos the pizza like here  It must be good, Irsquom thinking, because itrsquos .pm on a Sunday night, theyrsquore closing in a few minutes yet therersquos a steady stream through the door.And, generally, it is good. We have slices of the last baked tray from the oven. Margharita ndash thick, puffed up, richly crusted, maybe a little bready but undeniably fresh.The sausage and onion that Cal and Seona share is as it should be. The potato pizza has finely sliced, crisply-edged slices but maybe lacks seasoning. There are more rectangles to taste and try, all exhibiting the Roman style of pizza toppings as art.Maybe a bit more work on the bases, which y in rise, but as we arrived near to closing time there was only that margharita available still hot from the bake. Better to check again when theyrsquore in full flow.There are two rice balls stuffed with cheese too, suppli to you and me, pre-fried and then, because the fryer is now off, reheated in an oven. Not hugely successfully.Therersquos a moment of excitement at a pepperonata topped slice with actual still-rare-in-Scottish-restaurants stracchino, but it turns out to have been substituted with burrata ndash a less pugnacious Italian cheese. Such is le in the last orders lane. Good shout though. And dferent. How long now till the cult fried Neapolitan pizza fritta arrives on these shores  Make it soon please.Baked pizza al taglioDuke StreetGlasgow  Menu: Traditional Italian pizza by the slice. Full marks for the range of toppings, the authentic ingredients and even the authentic cans of Nuova Ricetta Oran soda.  Service Itrsquos self-service at the counter but friendly, chatty staff and a feel that they know therersquos a bit of a buzz about the place.  Atmosphere: It ainrsquot Italy in the east end but nothing wrong with a plain Jane interior made reasonably comfortable.  Price: Tricky one, this, as the slices are small but then the toppings are large and the prices are OK at pound. for pepperoni, pound. for Calabrian sausage. Extremely reasonable soft drinks and dirt cheap Suppli.  Food: Get there when theyrsquore just coming out of the oven and itrsquos well worth the visit. Proper Italian al taglio with great toppings, more work on the base perhaps.

title: climate-for-change-newton-property-management-vows-to-be-a-force-for-good
story: Stephen OrsquoNeill, of Newton Property ManagementWhen Newton Property Management was incorporated in  by founder Stephen OrsquoNeill the notion of a nationwide charging system for Electric Vehicleswas the stuff of science fiction. Fast-forward to today, however, and Scotland is already set to ban sales of combustion-powered cars by , with only Battery Electric Vehicles and Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicles allowed.Itrsquos a game-changing decision and one that will demand major investment in our charging infrastucture.Thankfully, Newton ndash a major new partner of The Heraldrsquos Climate for Change campaign ndash are leading the charge to see Scotland embrace this more sustainable, environmentally-friendly future.Serving tens of thousands of customers and one of the countryrsquos most sought-after, pro-active property factors, they have set aside an initial giveaway fund of pound, for the first phase of an EV charging point initiative ndash and want to have upwards of  charge points installed by .Itrsquos a move that reflects chairman and joint managing director OrsquoNeillrsquos vision to promote innovation and inspire community responsibility.ldquoWhen I started Newton, I knew a modern factor could be a force for good and for change, he says. ldquoWe have truly shaken up the industry with our can-do, modern, friendly attitude.Itrsquos this attitude that has seen Newton grow at a rate of over % per annum to become one of the top five privately-owned factoring companies in Scotland.Now this same dynamism is focussed on boosting the uptake of EV charging points ldquoWe want to shake things up again and take a lead ndash make others think about whatrsquos possible, OrsquoNeill says.ldquoWe want to help our clients future-proof their developments and take advantage of new eco technologies, saving them money. Itrsquos a win-win!He adds: ldquoOur customers are fed up waiting for the Government to take a lead on this. It will be a massive undertaking for Newton, which operates from three regional bases in Glasgow, Aberdeen and Inverness, with a client portfolio that ranges from Gretna Green to Tain.However, for joint managing director Derek MacDonald, who joined the business in , the project is hugely important.Derek MacDonald, above, says he and like-minded directors want to plan for the next generation.ldquoWe are super-aware of our responsibilities to our customers and to the environment, he says.ldquoWe are a young, modern, family-orientated company. I can see my fellow young directors growing with the business and bringing up their young families. When I think of their future, and our customers and their families, I want to believe by taking a lead we can help make a dference to this and the next generation and their quality of le.However, MacDonald admits no one is ldquo bleary eyed about the undertaking ndash there is a commercial reality driven by an eco-responsible narrative.He points out: ldquoThose businesses who do not step up and take responsibility will eventually pay the price and lack new customers. We want to bring our unique vision and service delivery to as many customers as quickly as possible and we know how to do this, by not only driving change, but anticipating change and then meeting demand.Ross Watt, Managing Director-North Scotland for Newton Property ManagementHe believes installing EV charging points in customersrsquo developments is a case in point.ldquoAll Scottish cities are moving towards emission control zones to restrict the use of older vehicles ... and moving quickly. If you truly want to protect your investment and futureproof your development, come and talk to us, we have the solutions for you. We are fully committed to delivering change.He notes the campaign for change may start off with only one charge point in a visitor space in a car park for a block of flats ndash butitrsquos a choice between none and one, the first one can convince someone to buy an EV.ldquoThen we install the second and a third, he says. ldquoItrsquos classic chicken and egg scenario. We are talking to ownersrsquo associations in several large city centre developments throughout the country with a view to pre-wiring electricity supplies to every car park space. Hundreds of them.ldquoOur customers arenrsquot daft. They know they will have to do this at some point and we will help them deliver this and secure their investment.Ultimately, he notes, the initiative has to be a joint effort by customers and the industry.ldquoThe biggest single privilege of being a property factor has to be the ability to help guide the narrative. Call it a form of persuasive soft power. It also has to be our customers who decide what happens ndash itrsquos their properties, after all. But wouldnrsquot you rather work with a factor who has a clear lsquorsquo vision "William Cowie, of Newton Property ManagementVISION FOR THE PLANETNewtons management portfolio is nationwide and consists of ,-plus factored clients and  letting clients. The company insures property with a reinstatement value in excess of pound billion.Turnover for  is expected to be pound. million with transactional cash flow in excess of pound millionIt has five directors, three of whom are under  years old.Its multi-pronged eco initiative sets out clear and achievable objectives by the year , including:The Herald is delighted to welcome new partner Newton Property Management to its Climate For Change campaign. Updates every Thursday in the Herald and quarterly in Business HQ magazine. To become a partner contact Stephen McTaggart on    stephen.mctaggart@heraldandtimes

title: theresa-mays-deputy-tells-tory-plotters-to-rally-behind-her-in-the-national-interest
story: Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington insisted Tory rebels plotting her downfall ldquohavenrsquot got a better alternative plan available and should rally behind her in the national interest.He also challenged Nicola Sturgeon to put ldquoliving standards and prosperity in Scotland first and back Mrs Mayrsquos draft Brexit orce deal, insisting EU leaders had made clear there is no appetite for renegotiation.Speaking to the media in Edinburgh, Mr Lidington said: ldquoI think anybody who works closely with the Prime Minister, as I do, learns what an absolutely backbreaking job that is.ldquoWith each day that passes, even more this week, I am so impressed with the Prime Ministerrsquos resilience and her strength of character.ldquoI sometimes wonder what it is that makes her get up in the morning and come in and face the disobliging headlines and cartoons.ldquoAnd actually what it is, I know her down to sitting in meetings with her and talking to her, itrsquos a very old fashioned sense of public service and public duty.ldquoShersquos not somebody who goes in for grandstanding, showboating for media opportunities, shersquos there for very decent, old-fashioned sense of public duty.ldquoAnd I would say to people who are plotting against her ndash this is a woman who is intensely patriotic, intensely dutul who is doing her utmost for families and businesses in every corner of this country.ldquoThey havenrsquot got a better alternative plan available to the one that she has worked on, and they should rally behind her because thatrsquos what the national interest asks of them.The Prime Minister has faced mounting speculation about her future after key figures, including Brexit secretary Dominic Raab, dramatically quit her Cabinet because they could not support the proposed withdrawal deal.Meanwhile, several Tory MPs have submitted letters of no confidence in Mrs May, with sources now indicating the number sent to Sir Graham Brady, the chair of the backbench  Committee, may be nearing the  needed to trigger a leadership challenge.Mr Lidington laughed off suggestions he is being lined up as a ldquocaretaker Prime MinisterMrs May is forced out, adding: ldquoI think that anyone who has seen what being Prime Minister involved is quickly cured of any ambition in that direction.The Cabinet Office Minister also moved to reassure Scottish Tory MPs concerned about plans to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland.Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson and Scottish Secretary David Mundell previously threatened to resignNorthern Ireland was treated dferently to the rest of the UK ndash fearing it could undermine the Union and boost Scottish independence.Mr Lidington said ldquobackstop proposals which would see Northern Ireland more closely aligned with EU rules had ldquoalways been conceived as an insurance policy only and there was a determination they wouldnrsquot be implemented.But he rebuffed SNP calls for Scotland to receive similar treatment, adding: ldquoI think that the history of Northern Ireland ndash the fact that there is still a fragile peace building process after decades of bitter and bloodthirsty conflict, means that there is a special circumstance that applies in Northern Ireland.ldquoAnd that land border ndash the only land border the UK has with any other country in the EU ndash has both an economic but also a real political and talismanic signicance that doesnrsquot apply anywhere .ldquoItrsquos a mixture of the practical and the political that is at work here.Mr Lidington called on the First Minister to support Mrs Mayrsquos deal to protect jobs and the economy.He said: ldquoI think there will be an important choice for the Scottish Government and for Scottish members of parliament at Westminster.ldquoEmployers in all sectors want a deal, and they want the stability and the certainty and the clarity that that will bring.ldquoAnd I hope very much that, despite the political dferences that do exist, and which I respect, that the First Minister will in the end decide to put the interests of Scottish business and living standards and prosperity in Scotland first and support this deal.ldquoWe, for our part, will continue to listen to the views of the Scottish and Welsh governments, to engage with them as we have been doing in recent days, weeks and months and to ensure that their interests are represented and defended in negotiations.He said Ms Sturgeon had refused to meet him during his visit to Edinburgh ndash a claim the First Minister branded ldquooutrageous.She said her office was given short notice and she ldquowasnrsquot prepared to cancel my constituency commitments at such short notice for the Scottish Government to yet again have to hear empty platitudes rather than be listened to.

title: scottish-football-hero-kenny-dalglish-receives-knighthood
story: Known as King Kenny on Merseyside, the former player and manager said it was his duty to "turn supporter" and help Liverpool families in the aftermath of the Hillsborough football tragedy in .Sir Kenny was dubbed a knight by the Prince of Wales during a Buckingham Palace investiture ceremony for services to football, charity and the city of Liverpool.Speaking after the ceremony, Sir Kenny said about the Hillsborough families: "They were fantastically supportive of the football club and at that instance it was important for us to turn supporter."They needed a bit of help, we wanted to help them, and Im sure they would have done the same for us - I think thats what le is all about."Sir Kenny was the Scottish international striker who became a star of English football when he filled the gap left by the departing Liverpool hero Kevin Keegan at Anfield after a trophy-laden spell at Celtic.He went on to become a Kop legend, winning three European Cups and six league titles with the club.As a manager he performed the rare feat of winning top-flight league championship titles with two dferent clubs, Liverpool and Blackburn Rovers.Speaking about becoming a Sir, he said: "You feel humble. When you start off in your le, what do you want  You just want to play football."And when you play football, what do you want to do  You want to try and be successful, be a professional footballer, try and win something."

title: amber-rudd-returns-to-cabinet-as-work-and-pensions-secretary
story: Meanwhile, Leave-supporting Stephen Barclay has been promoted to Brexit Secretary from a ministerial role in the Department for Health.The reshuffle came just hours after Michael Gove offered the Prime Minister a leline by staying on in his Cabinet role.Environment Secretary Mr Gove insisted he still has confidence in Mrs May who has suffered a series of setbacks following the publication of her draft Brexit deal with Brussels.She has suffered the loss of four ministers and faces continued speculation that a vote of no confidence in her leadership could be triggered by Tory MPs within days.Read more:Theresa Mays deputy tells Tory plotters to rally behind her in the national interestMs Rudd was a prominent Remain campaigner during the referendum and herto the Cabinet, in place of Brexiteer Esther McVey who resigned on Thursday, may do little to bridge ides within the Tory ranks.The rehabilitation of Ms Rudd, who quit in a row over immigration targets, comes after a report concluded she had been let down by her officials.Mr Barclays appointment came after Mr Gove reportedly turned down the post after saying he would only take ithe could renegotiate the EU withdrawal agreement.Speaking outside his departmental office, Environment Secretary Mr Gove was askedhe had confidence in the Prime Minister and replied: "I absolutely do."He added: "I am looking forward to continuing to work with all colleagues in Government and in Parliament to get the best future for Britain."A Downing Street spokeswoman said Mrs May was "very pleased" that Mr Gove will stay on and "continue doing the important work he is doing".

title: kevin-mckenna-brexit-mess-shows-how-little-westminster-thinks-of-scotland
story: Instead, let it be a simple production created in the manner of those edgy found-footage films with scared faces and shaky images of an unfolding apocalypse. Perhaps it might be called  Hours in Westminster and it would feature a seemingly random selection of words and pictures from the period between pm on Wednesday, November ,  and the same time the following day. Therersquos Theresa May, the signs of emotional dishevelment lining her drawn features, emerging from her Downing Street bunker to tell us that the cabinet has just backed her Brexit draft withdrawal agreement. There she is again  hours later featuring in a live three-hour political evisceration on the floor of the House of Commons, her voice reduced to a croak as she repeats the phrase ldquotake back control, ldquotake back control, ldquotake back control.This would be interspersed with shots of a familiar cast of hard right spectres flitting in and out of the picture. Therersquos Nigel Farage, the millionaire former stockbroker, telling us about being the little man taking on the political elite. Now itrsquos another millionaire, Jacob Rees-Mogg, his grin, like that of his political hero Sir Robert Peel, resembling ldquothe reflection of a sunbeam on a coffin plate. There are as yet unconfirmed reports that Rees-Mogg has asked his fellow Brexiteers on the European Research Group soon to start working on re-negotiating the Magna Carta.David Davis, the former Brexit minister, is trying not to grin as he revives memories of Geoffrey Boycottrsquos straight bat. Now his successor is telling us he felt moved to resign from his post because he could not support the document for which he had been chiefly responsible. Of course we now know that there have been more sightings of Lord Lucan in Brussels these past two years than of this hapless pair. And then therersquos the draft withdrawal agreement itself where the name of every country in the world is mentioned save those of Scotland and Freedonia.In February, , the then Prime Minister, David Cameron, made a speech in London in which he spoke about how the rest of the UK would be diminishedScotland were to leave. He said: ldquoThe UK is the big European success story of this century moving from an island sinking under too much debt, too much borrowing and too much taxation to a country thatrsquos dynamic, exporting, innovating, creating. Scotland is right at the heart of that vision.Not even the most fervent of Scottish Unionists could have predicted how quickly Scotland would fall out of the picture. When Mrs May was taken to task at the absence of any mention of Scotland in the -page document she replied that this wasnrsquot necessary as Scotland was part of the United Kingdom. Few in the SNP were expecting anything more than this and certainly not Mike Russell, formerly the Scottish Governmentrsquos Minister for UK Negotiations on Scotlandrsquos Place in Europe. Earlier this year he spoke to me about some of his frustrations in this role. These principally arose from the large number of joint ministerial meetings that were cancelled by the UK Government during his tenure. You couldnrsquot even accuse the UK Government of treating Scotland with contempt during the Brexit process. To treat someone with contempt you must at least engage with them.Such contempt as the UK Government has shown to Scotland has never been in evidence in its dealings with Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionist Party. That relationship was founded on a bribe of hard cash and is maintained in the same way that rich Victorians once conducted illicit relationships with the domestic staff. Thus, ten representatives of a gerrymandered region created for the sole purpose of reinforcing the cultural superiority of one people over another, were able to take ownership of the entire Brexit process. It remains to be seen what further financial inducements the British state will slip furtively into the hands of the DUP to secure their support for the draft agreement.Accompanying every interview across each of the UKrsquos main television and radio news channels these last three days a persistent drumbeat could be heard. Its message never ceased: ldquoTaking back control of our borders taking back control of our laws. It was espoused by Tory Brexiteers and Remainers alike. Itrsquos easy to forget that they only disagree on minutiae and that they all coalesce around the same over-arching principles: that all dodgy foreigners must be kept out and that the industrial relations enjoyed by th century mill-owners must be regained.The Conservative MP Anne Marie Morris also featured heavily in the political coverage. In , she was one of  landlord MPs who voted down an amendment on rental homes being ldquofit for human habitation. She and her financier husband once featured in a newspaper series about how affluent families could ldquolimit their tax liabilities. On Wednesday night she said that of course Brexit would be ldquobumpy without admitting that it would be somewhat smoother for her. Itrsquos the same approach deployed by her spiritual mentor in the European Research Group, Mr Rees-Mogg who last month said that the ramications of Brexit might not be known for  years. Only people with very large fortunes and estates can speak with such insouciance about actions and their consequences.What we have witnessed these last few days isnrsquot really about the entire future of the UK as the BBCrsquos Laura Kuenssberg pronounced with solemn gravity. Itrsquos about what happens when a small group of the UKrsquos richest and most powerful people quarrel about how best to maintain their hegemony. Carelessly, they also let slip that Scotland and its people occupy not a second of their thoughts.Supporters of independence are naivethey think that any Scot who is satisfied with this arrangement can ever be persuaded by the SNPs economic arguments. We are dealing with something much deeper and more primeval here.

title: theresa-may-appoints-low-profile-minister-stephen-barclay-as-new-brexit-secretary-as-amber-rudd-returns-to-frontline
story: In a dramaticto the Cabinet frontline, Amber Rudd becomes the Work and Pensions Secretary just seven months after resigning as Home Secretary over the Windrush scandal.No  pointed out how Mr Barclay,  and a father-of-two, who represents North East Cambridgeshire, voted to Leave in the  EU referendum.He was previously Minister of State in the Health Department, working before that as a whip and then as the Economic Secretary to the Treasury.Askedhe was the Prime Ministerrsquos first choice for the job ndash Michael Gove is believed to have turned it down - her spokesman said: ldquoHe was the PMrsquos choice for the jobhellipHe has experience across the Government.He explained how the negotiations were now in their ldquoend state with  days remaining. The PM would be leading them rather than Mr Barclay, which is a departure from the focus of his predecessor, Dominic Raab.Mr Barclay would be in charge of ldquodomestic delivery of Brexit and the preparedness for that, which included both a deal and no-deal scenarios. The spokesman said the new Cabinet minister would be in charge of the implementation of leaving the EU, which would involve taking the lead on taking legislation through Parliament.In another appointment, No  announced Surrey MP Kwasi Kwarteng, will join Mr Barclay at the Department for Exiting the European Union as a junior minister, replacing Suella Braverman, who also resigned earlier this week.The PMrsquos spokesman explained Mr Barclay would be ldquodealing with the domestic preparedness for Brexit. In terms of the negotiationshellipthe PM will be doing those.He said, following the draft withdrawal agreement and an outline political declaration, the focus in the next two weeks would be on turning that declaration into a more substantial future framework, which will eventually become a legally-binding treaty.ldquoThat is what is currently being negotiated and that is what will be put to Parliament alongside the Withdrawal AgreementhellipSo the Withdrawal Agreement is subject to us negotiating over the course of these coming days and having a framework which delivers on the referendum and represents a good deal for the UK.The ministerial rehabilitation of Ms Rudd, who quit in a row over immigration targets, comes after a report concluded she had been let down by her officials at the Home Office.The Hastings MP was a prominent Remain campaigner during the referendum and herto the Cabinet, in place of Brexiteer Esther McVey who resigned on Thursday, underpins how most of the main portfolios are held by those who opposed Brexit in .The PMrsquos spokesman said Ms Rudd was a ldquovery experienced Secretary of State, who has worked across a number of departments and had important work to do at the Work and Pensions Department such as implementing the Universal Credit programme.ldquoThe PM is confident she will do an excellent job, he insisted.In other appointments, Stephen Hammond, who represents Wimbledon, becomes a Minister of State in the Department of Health and Social Care. A Remainer, he was sacked in  as party vice-chairman after he rebelled on the EU Withdrawal Bill.Meanwhile, John Penrose, a Remainer-turned-Brexiteer, who is MP for Weston-super-Mare, becomes a Minister of State in the Northern Ireland Office.Further appointments will be made later today, Downing Street said.

title: stephen-barclay-becomes-mays-third-brexit-secretary-but-role-now-has-different-emphasis
story: No  was keen to point out that the unexpected appointee, who represents North East Cambridgeshire, voted Leave in the  referendum but was also keen to point out that his role would not be the same as his predecessor Dominic Raab.Now that the negotiating phase of the withdrawal agreement is over, Mr Barclayrsquos role is to lead on the ldquodomestic delivery of Brexit in the context of preparing for it whether there is a deal or no deal, particularly in terms of getting the necessary legislation through Parliament. So, the new Secretary of State will be spending all of his time at Westminster and not Brussels.Before yesterday, no one had tipped Mr Barclay as the new Secretary of State but the role is no longer as important as it once was and when Britain leaves the EU next March it is possible the job will no longer exist.The youngest of three brothers, his father was a trade union official while his mother worked in the civil service.Raised in Lancashire, he attended an independent school and before studying history at Cambridge and then law in Chester, he used a gap year to attend the military academy at Sandhurst, serving briefly as a second lieutenant with the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.As a qualied solicitor, the -year-old father-of-two worked for a London law firm and became an MP in Cambridgeshire in , having failed twice in previous contests in Manchester and Lancaster.Under Theresa Mayrsquos premiership, Mr Barclay has risen quickly through the ranks, becoming at first a whip, then Economic Secretary to the Treasury and then as Minister of State for Health before rising to his new Cabinet role.

title: analysis-brexit-is-a-parliamentary-numbers-game-and-may-at-present-doesnt-have-them
story: And at present, Theresa May doesnrsquot look as though she is anywhere near having the numbers to get her wobbly draft withdrawal agreement with Brussels through the House of Commons.After what has been the most testing week of her premiership, the Prime Minister has survived but only just.A key moment came at .am on Friday when Michael Gove issued a statement of support for his leader. It came against expectations at Westminster.When, on Thursday night, the Environment Secretary turned down the role of Brexit Secretary because Mrs May had refused his request to be able to change the draft deal, it seemed the writing was on the wall.How,Mr Gove thought the deal needed to be renegotiated, could he possibly carry on Having been the "assassin" for his onetime chums Cameron and Johnson, what would it have said for his capacity for loyaltythe Scot had wielded the kne a third time By rallying round, Mr Gove helped shore up support for Mrs May, preventing the likes of fellow Brexiteers, Mordaunt, Grayling and Leadsom handing in their resignations.Next week, the PM faces yet another challenge: the threat of a no-confidence vote. But the rebels, having expressed initial confidence they have the  signatures needed to spark a vote, appear increasingly dfident they can secure one.AndMrs May won any vote, her detractors could not challenge her for another year.Tory whips will be busy this week ringing round colleagues, warning them against joining the rebellion, saying it could end with an even greater disaster: a Corbyn government.Intriguingly, while London and Brussels have been adamant there can be no renegotiation of the draft agreement, Leave ministers like Gove, Leadsom, Mordaunt and Grayling are set to meet next week to seethey can push the Brexit door open a bit. There is even talk of the Pizza-clubbers Hunt, Hammond and Javid joining forces in the campaign.The aim is to change the current backstop exit mechanism, which has so antagonised the pro-Brexiteers namely, the UK can only leave the backstop with the EUrsquos say-so.The argument isthis could be amended in some way to allow ndash what in all other walks of le happens ndash free will so Britain could walk away at the moment of its choosing, then the draft deal just might make it through the parliamentary quagmire.At present, the prospect of the draft deal getting through the Commons looks hopeless. It had been thought Mrs May could, given the tranche of Leave and Remain rebels, possibly rely on Labour moderates to push the Brexit withdrawal blueprint over the line.But the Labour moderates as well as the opposition forces as a whole believethe May deal is rejected, Britainrsquos sovereign Parliament could ldquotake charge and propose another vote with the option of staying in.This is why the PM this week dropped into the public consciousness the three-way choice of her deal, a no-deal or a no Brexit.As Labour figures begin to use more positive language about a Peoplersquos Vote, the SNP appear to be warming to it greatly too.Yet, of course, there is also the little matter of indyref and when Nicola Sturgeon will make her big demand.Earlier this week, much to the chagrin of some of her parliamentary colleagues, the First Minister again adopted a wait-and-see position even though we now know the broad terms of the draft withdrawal agreement.It seems clear, politically, Ms Sturgeon will make her call on the back of what she feels is the moment of maximum disruption for the Tory Government, which, at present, looks like the aftermath of the meaningful vote at Westminster.But, everything to do with Brexit is a gamble. Whatthe PM won the vote In any case, Mrs May has said in the clearest of terms she would not facilitate another vote on Scotlandrsquos future any time soon itrsquos in the Tory manesto.But whatthe PM lost that vote  Would she struggle on  Would she resign  Who would take over  Would there be a general election  Would Parliament succeed in tabling a motion for a Peoplersquos Vote Only one thing is certain: Britainrsquos Brexit nightmare would rumble on.

title: he-is-my-rock-theresa-may-on-the-man-firmly-in-her-corner
story: As Mrs May faced resignations, threats of a coup and personal attacks over her Brexit deal, her husband of  years was on hand to provide much-needed moral support.After she finally ed home to the Downing Street flat following Wednesdayrsquos fiery five-hour Cabinet meeting, the first thing he did was to pour her a whisky, the PM revealed.ldquoOn Thursday, he served up beans on toast for tea, she said, in an interview with the Daily Mail. ldquoI opened the tin! He made the toast ndash and did the washing up!With furious backlash against Mrs May over her Brexit plan ndash and demands for a no-confidence vote against her ndash her husband could not help but feel the hurt of the situation too, she admitted.ldquoItrsquos often harder for the other half because they are watching it and feel protective and think lsquoWhy are they saying that to my we rsquo, she added.But despite the turmoil, Mrs May has remained defiant and has vowed to fight on and deliver Brexit, with her husband firmly in her corner.ldquoHe is my rock, she said.ldquoItrsquos hugely important to have somebody there who is supportive of you, not involved in the intricacies of politics but there to provide human support.Mr and Mrs May were married in  after meeting as students at Oxford University. title: hundreds-of-chinese-lanterns-light-up-edinburgh-zoo
story: Unicorns, kelpies, a sleeping dragon and Nessie the Loch Ness Monster are among the creatures on display in The Giant Lanterns of China event.Two hundred specialists from China spent more than  days creating the trail around the venue, with this yearrsquos themeinspired by the Scottish tradition of storytelling, the Royal Zoological Society of Scotlandrsquoswildle conservation work, endangered animals and the cultural heritage of Sichuan.The trail featuresmore than  handmade lanterns constructed with , metres of fabric and , LED lights.Barbara Smith, chief executive at RZSS Edinburgh Zoo, said: ldquoOver  nights, Edinburgh Zoo will be transformed into a winter wonderland of myths and legends brought to le through hundreds of colossal Chinese lanterns.ldquoThis yearrsquos event is bigger and better than ever and visitors will come face to face with herds of unicorns, kelpies, a sleeping dragon and Nessie the Loch Ness Monster.ldquoEach installation tells a story from Scottish legends and Chinese mythology as well as the crucial conservation projects we undertake with our partners to help preserve the worldrsquos most vulnerable species.ldquoThe event is a chance for us to illuminate the critical conservation work of RZSS to protect endangered animals and the real risk of them becoming myths and legends for future generations.The event runs until February , andtickets are available at edinburghzoo.org.uk lanterns.

title: johnston-press-boss-reassures-staff-as-they-prepare-for-restructure
story: In an email to staff,David King said the publisher will apply for court approval to be sold to a newly-incorporated group of companies controlled by creditors.It informed staff they would continue to be paid and should turn up to work as normal, with their contracts to be transferred to the new company.Mr King is set to stay on as chief executive and said ldquooperations will continue uninterrupted, with newspapers and websites being published as usual.He said: ldquoThis has not been an easy decision for the board.ldquoHowever, having explored a range of other options, this is the best available course of action and it is one that offers a chance for a brighter future for our business.One of Britainrsquos biggest publishers,it has more than  titles in print and online, including the i, The Yorkshire Post and The Scotsman.Very concerning news ndash makes stark reality of the intense pressures on the press https:t.co knEfUhSoPzmdash Matt HancockNovember , The publisher had recently been looking at ways to refinance pound million of debt which is due to be repaid in June next year.In the email to staff, Mr King said: ldquoAt its peak, the companyrsquos debt reached pound million.ldquoWe have all worked incredibly hard to reduce those debts. And we have done so against a relentlessly tough market backdrop.At its most recent trading update, Johnston reported a hit to revenues, mostly due to changes in Google and Facebook algorithms.Mr King said this meant the company had to ldquore-cut our cloth to match the new reality.In a statement from Johnston on Friday, the publisher said ldquofollowing considerable interest in the formal sales title: lady-sylvia-hermon-needs-assurances-from-pm-to-back-eu-withdrawal-deal

title: river-clyde-waterfront-project-approved-by-scottish-government
story: Scottish ministers approved the scheme on Friday after two years of public engagement.The Clyde Waterfront and Renfrew Riverside initiative will include the construction of the first opening road bridge over the River Clyde, linking Renfrew and Yoker.It is is expected to plough pound million into the local economy and create , new jobs.Renfrewshire Council leader Iain Nicolson said: ldquoThe completed project and subsequent regeneration has the potential to deliver a signicant economic boost to the Glasgow City region.ldquoCurrent businesses will gain access to more customers and suppliers, while new companies and developers will be attracted to locate to the regenerated waterfront.ldquoCommunities on both sides of the Clyde will benefit from greatly improved access to their work, to education and to hospitals through the new connections, which will also help reduce congestion and improve journey times.The crossing has been designed by engineering consultancy Sweco working with Kettle Collective, architects behind the Falkirk Wheel.New roads, walkways and cycle routes into a -acre site next to Glasgow Airport are also included.Funding for the project comes from thepound. billion Glasgow City Deal.

title: sign-up-to-agreement-or-face-chaotic-no-deal-brexit-says-simon-coveney
story: Simon Coveney said people are ldquotoo quick to write off Prime Minister Theresa May, saying she has shown ldquoresilience, courage and a ldquoreality check to Brexiteers in Westminster.He title: soyuz-cargo-launch-paves-way-for-next-crew-to-visit-space-station
story: The launch of the Russian Progress MS- resupply ship from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan marked the fourth successful lt-off of a Soyuz since a launch with crew members had to be aborted last month.A Soyuz-FG rocket carrying Nasa astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmosrsquo Alexei Ovchinin failed two minutes into its flight on October , activating an automatic rescue system that ensured a safe landing of their capsule.A Russian investigation attributed the failure to a sensor that was damaged during the rocketrsquos final assembly.Since the mishap, two Soyuz rockets were launched successfully from Plesetsk in northwestern Russia, while a third lted off from French Guiana carrying satellites into orbit.They were of a dferent subtype than the rocket that failed in October, but the one that lted off Friday was the same version.The Progress ship is set to dock at the space station on Sunday, delivering almost three tons of food, fuel, water and other supplies to the crew, Nasarsquos Serena Aunon-Chancellor, Russian Sergei Prokopyev and German Alexander Gerst.Russias Progress cargo craft blasted off on its way to the station today at :pm ET. title: sir-tom-devine-slave-based-economies-impacted-on-lives-of-most-scots
story: To a considerable extent the programmes were structured around the findings of the edited collection, Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past Edinburgh University Press , the first wide-ranging academic analysis to be published of Scotlandrsquos connections to transatlantic slavery.One of the points of contention raised by some viewers concerns the gains from slavery in the th and early th centuries and the extent to which they may or may not have percolated downwards beyond the ranks of the mercantile elites and plantation owners to the population in general. As the editor of Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past, I try in what follows to inform the debate by presenting the most recent research findings on this question.One key point should be made at the start. Slave trading by ships which sailed directly from Scottish ports to West Africa with goods to exchange for slaves and thence on to the Americas with human cargoes was always a relatively limited activity and seems to have faded away completely after c.. On the other hand, eacutemigreacute Scots merchants, sea captains, seamen and physicians did play a very signicant role in the huge commerce in slaves emanating from Bristol, Liverpool and London.At abolition the British Government provided the vast sum of pound millionin compensation to those who would lose their ldquoproperty in slaves. According to the UCL conclusions, Scottish absentee slave owners were more likely to be rewarded on a per capita basis than their counterparts where in the British Isles.Those compensated came from theand breadth of Scotland, from the Highlands to the Borders, and were not concentrated in Glasgow and the west which for many decades had the closest commercial connections across the Atlantic. Further, not only landed grandees and trading tycoons were compensated. Among the moneyed classes it was not uncommon in the early th century to own slaves as security for interest-bearing loans to colonial trading concerns.Thus, widows, minors, annuitants, clerics, lawyers, professors, shopkeepers, tenant farmers and many others were eventually awarded lump sums as part of the compensation process after abolition. The social mix of the middle classes who profited from slavery was therefore both wide and deep. Slavery and slave ownership spread throughout Scottish finance and commerce before  to an extant unequalled anywhere  in the UK outside the City of London.But this was not all. Among the Scottish external trades of the period c. to c. three commodities were dominant at dferent periods. Before the outbreak of the American War of Independence, tobacco from Virginia, Maryland and North Carolina was king. In the early s Glasgow and its outports imported more American leaf than London and all other English ports combined exported mainly to European markets, tobacco made up more than half of all Scottish exports by value by the early s.After  its hegemony was overtaken by trade to the Caribbean in sugar, rum, cotton and indigo. Inwent manufactured goods, especially ldquoslave cloth from the mills of Scotlandrsquos infant industrial revolution and the linen workers of the East of Scotland. By the end of the Napoleonic Wars in  three-fths of all Scottish exports were bound for the West Indian islands.Then there was cotton. It first came in ships from the Caribbean but that source was quickly superseded from the s by the plantations of the southern USA which alone had the capacity to satisfy the gargantuan appetite of the many new factories for raw material to transform into cotton cloth, the manufacture of which became the leading sector of the Scottish industrial revolution.These three enterprises all had one key feature in common: they could not have existed and then flourished without hard labour in the tobacco, sugar and cotton fields across the Atlantic by armies of black men, women and children bound for le in chattel slavery.Furthermore, merchant profits from these trades did much to provide the capital for Scottish industrialism. The country was one of the poorest in western Europe before c. but paradoxically it managed to fund not only new manufacturing development but also fast urban expansion on an unprecedented scale and a parallel transformation of agriculture and rural society.How so  Fortunes made by some Scots in India were one source but the most crucial was capital flowing from American and Caribbean commerce based on slave labour.These processes came together to establish the material basis for modernisation. Hence few Scots who lived in the th and early th centuries could have been immune from the direct or indirect impact of the slave-based economies on their lives whether or not they were active in the ldquonefarious trade itself.Those involved in slavery have long gone but their legacy lives on in country houses, university and school benefactions, church buildings, statues, civic institutions, museum collections and much more. For those who care to look, it is all around.For those interested in finding out more see TM Devinersquos Did Slavery Make Scotia Great  in TM Devine ed Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past .Sir Tom Devine is Sir William Fraser Professor Emeritus of Scottish History and Palaeography in the University of Edinburgh.

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: IF none of those float your boat, you could always opt for a cool bagndash not at all tragic in any way, shape or form, you understand ndash for just pound, complete with Stronger For Scotland branding. title: argentina-submarine-found-sunk-a-year-after-disappearing-navy-says
story: The ARA San Juan was detected more than , feet deep in waters off the Valdes Peninsula in Argentine Patagonia, a statement said.The navy said a ldquopositive identication had been made by a remote-operated submersible from the American ship Ocean Infinity, which was hired for the latest search for the missing vessel.The discovery was announced just two days after families of the missing sailors held a commemoration one year after the sub disappeared on November , .On Thursday, on the anniversary of the disappearance, Argentinarsquos president Mauricio Macri said the families of the submariners should not feel alone and delivered an ldquoabsolute and non-negotiable commitment to find ldquothe truth.He promised a full investigation after the submarine was lost. Federal police raided naval bases and other buildings last January as part of the probe, soon after the government dismissed the head of the navy.The San Juan was ing to its base in the coastal city of Mar del Plata when contact was lost.Argentina gave up hope of finding survivors after an intense search aided by  countries, but the navy has continued searching for the vessel.The German-built diesel-electric TR- class submarine was commissioned in the mid-s and was most recently refitted between  and .During the retrofitting, the vessel was cut in half and had its engines and batteries replaced. Experts said refits can be dficult because they involve integrating systems produced by dferent manufacturers, and even the tiniest mistake during the cutting phase can put the safety of the ship and crew at risk.The navy said previously the captain reported on November  that water had entered the snorkel and caused one of the subrsquos batteries to short-circuit. The captain later communicated that it had been contained.Some hours later, an explosion was detected near the time and place where the San Juan was last heard from.The navy said the blast could have been caused by a ldquoconcentration of hydrogen triggered by the battery problem reported by the captain.

title: council to consider setting wheels in motion for kintore blackburn link
story: A new #, pedestrian and cycle route linking Kintore and Blackburn is expected to be approved by councillors.Aberdeenshire Council has been providing new facilities along the A corridor for cyclists on a phased basis.Phase one began in  with a shared use path linking Kintore to the town’s business park, while phase two works have recently been completed linking Kintore with Inverurie.That route is already proving a hit with pedestrians, with an average of  daily users recorded during October.Now the local authority is seeking a decision on a favoured option for phase three works to provide a shared use path between Kintore and Blackburn.In a paper to the Garioch Area Committee which meets tomorrow , infrastructure services director Stephen Archer says the route would essentially provide a facility for cyclists wishing to commute onwards to Aberdeen.Discussions are currently ongoing with Aberdeen City Council with a view to the creation of a connection from the city to Blackburn.Mr Archer will report: “The proposal to develop the phase three works was included on the Procurement Work Plan which was approved at the Infrastructure Services Committee of March , .“A successful grant application was subsequently made to the Sustrans Community Links Programme and a % funding commitment has been made by Sustrans for the project.”A feasibility study was undertaken to identy four potential routes, with option two running adjacent to and north of the A and south via the A underpass being favoured by officers.Mr Archer continues: “While the report does not make a definitive recommendation on which route to take forward, on the basis of cost, implementation and socio-economic impact, option two is regarded as being the overall best value option.“It is therefore requested that option two is now taken forward for detailed design to create a design and tender package before the end of the current financial year that would allow the council to approach funding partners for construction funding for future years.”He will also indicate that while the third option of using the old turnpike road would perhaps not fulfil the requirements for a title: academy hosts art exhibition
story: Inverurie Academy held its second Art Exhibition on Thursday, November .The exhibition featured ious pieces of artwork by National , Higher and Advanced Higher pupils.Pupil Natalie Thomson with her work Pick  Mix TreatsHead of Creative Arts at Inverurie Academy, Olefine Richardson, said: “This year we have  National  exhibitors, ten Higher and one Advanced Higher.“The work on display is by our th, th and th year pupils.“This is the second year that we have held an art exhibition at the school and it is bigger than last year’s event.“The evening celebrates the pupils’ exceptional work and the phenomenal effort that they have put in to it.Many pupils created designs for new items including an apron, umbrella, and perfume boxes“We are really proud of them all and their hard work.”S Higher pupil Natalie Thomson had her work ‘ Pick  Mix Treats’ on display.Natalie said: “I chose Pick and Mix because it was fun to draw and I could eat it afterwards. title: football fans invited to share their memories
story: A Football Memories group held in Inverurie is encouraging more participants to come along and share their stories.The group, organised by Inverurie Loco Works FC and Alzheimer Scotland, uses memories of the sport to improve the lives of people with dementia and memory problems.Memories can be very effective in developing communication skills as well as boosting morale, self-confidence and self-esteem.The group uses old photographs, Football Memories cards, video footage and pieces of memorabilia to help its members recall players, teams, goals and stories from the past.Inverurie Loco Works FC set up the Football Memories group in  and meetingswere originally held in the club’s boardroom, dressing room, and social club.However after a few location changes the meetings are now held in Hanover Court, Inverurie.Community activity organiser for Alzheimer Scotland, Anouk Kahanov-Kloppert said: “Alzheimer Scotland is here to support people but anyone is welcome to come along, including ladies.“The group aims to stimulate memories from the past. Some of the stories we have heard so far have been facinating.“It’s amazing how people are connected with the past, and the meetings give those taking part a sense of well-being and purpose.”The Football Memories Scotland project is supported by the Scottish Football Museum at Hampden Park in Glasgow.The next meeting of theInverurie Football Memories group will be held onThursday, December .For more information or future meeting dates please call  .Transport to and from the group can be provided, for enquiries please contact Anouk by calling  .data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Macdonald Pittodrie House has been shortlisted for the Wedding of the Year category"  North east hotel makes award finals viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

story: Olympic swimmer Hannah Miley will officially open Inverurie#s Christmas Ice Rink on Saturday, December .The opening event will begin at .am.This is the first year that Inverurie has had an Ice Rink in the town as part of its Christmas celebrations.After the opening ceremony, Hannah will introduce a group of young figure skaters who regularly compete at a National level.The team will be wowing the crowds with a beautul figure skating performance prior to the rink opening to the public at am.Hannah said: “I’m really looking forward to this event.
